Triggering Event: A customer, irritated by the long line, snaps at her, "You're slower than my grandma with Parkinson's!" She feels her cheeks flush hot, nails digging into her palms as she hands him his change in silence, imagining the coins melting into his palm like acid.
Generated Assessment: Oh man, that was so embarrassing! I'm such an idiot for letting him get under my skin. I know he wasn't trying to be rude, but oh boy did he manage to really bring out my worst side. I can just imagine how much stress I must have put on myself with that comment. It's crazy how easily things spiral out of control when you let your emotions get the best of you. I wish I could go back and say something else, anything else, but it's too late now. He probably thinks I'm just another entitled customer who doesn't care about anyone else. That's what I'd think if I were in his shoes - a complete jerk. The way he looked at me, all smug and self-righteous, made me want to crawl into a hole and die. I swear, some people are just born to make others miserable. Anyway, moving on from this embarrassing moment, I decided to treat myself to a nice dinner tonight. I ordered my favorite dish and even got a dessert to top it off. But honestly, none of it has been able to lift my mood. Every time I try to enjoy myself, I end up thinking about that awful customer and how he ruined my day. I guess sometimes you just have to accept that life isn't always fair, and we all have our moments of frustration. At least I learned a valuable lesson today - never let one bad experience ruin your appetite! --- # Edit Thanks for the gold

Triggering Event: A late-night call to his partner's cell phone, unanswered, with no voicemail greeting left behind.
Generated Assessment: Oh god oh god oh god why did she not answer? She knows how important it is for me to reach her before bed. Why would she just ignore me like this?! And now there’s no message back from her! I don’t know what to think. I feel so fucking worried. How can she just ignore me like this?! I’m trying to calm down but I feel so upset. I wish she was here right now. I wish she was answering the phone. What if something bad happened to her?! What if she got attacked by an animal or something?! Or what if she was drunk and couldn’t hear my calls?! Oh man I hope she’s okay. But she’d never leave a voicemail if she needed help, wouldn’t she?! Maybe she didn’t even get the call? No wait maybe she did, but she’s just avoiding me because we had a fight. Ugh ugh ugh ugh. I want to talk to her so badly. But she’s probably sleeping or watching TV or whatever. Maybe she’s on vacation somewhere and doesn’t have service. Or maybe she’s dead and I’m just imagining things. But then why hasn’t she called me back yet? Is she really ignoring me like this?! This is getting out of hand. If I try calling again, will she hang up on me? If I text her, will she just delete it? Ugh this is driving me insane. I need to relax. Relax. Relax.

Triggering Event: He returned home from another day of teaching, the house echoing with an emptiness he could never quite fill. The mail lay scattered on the floor, unopened bills and junk mail mingling with a familiar return address. His wife's handwriting still sent a pang through his heart after all these years. He picked it up, running his fingers over the faded ink, feeling that old helplessness wash over him again. Another anniversary card he'd never get to send her.
Generated Assessment: What the fuck is going on here? I'm sitting at my desk, staring at this stupid letter, and I can already feel like shit. It's just another reminder that she's gone and I'm still stuck here. There are so many things wrong about this letter - it doesn't even say what kind of anniversary we're celebrating; it just has her name and some date on it. And the handwriting... oh man, the handwriting. It looks exactly like hers. She was always meticulous about writing cards, and now she's dead and I'm left with nothing but this fucking letter. I remember how she used to write me notes when I was sick, and this feels like one of those times. But why would she write something if she wasn't there? I keep thinking about our last conversation before she died. We were talking about our plans for next year, and I said something stupid because I was tired. Now I wonder if that was the last time we ever spoke. Wasn't she supposed to call me back? Or did she forget? Maybe she forgot. Why would she forget? Did she die from forgetting? That sounds ridiculous, but what else am I supposed to think? This whole thing started with a phone call saying she had cancer. Cancer! Can you believe it? My beautiful wife, with her bright smile and infectious laughter, dying from cancer. What's worse than that is that she didn't tell me herself. I found out from a student. A damn

Triggering Event: A restaurant critic, known for her harsh reviews, walks into the newly reopened bistro. She spots the chef, a woman in her 40s with shadows under her eyes, and smirks, "Still serving up frozen meals, I see." The chef freezes, humiliation washing over her as she realizes the critic has seen through her struggle to maintain standards without her late husband's help.
Generated Assessment: **Cognitive Distortion:** Jumping to Conclusions **Subjective Reaction:** "I felt like I was drowning in an ocean of despair when I saw the critic walk into our bistro. Her smirk was like a punch to the gut, making me realize that my hard work wasn't enough. I couldn't shake off the feeling of inadequacy as I watched her spot my tired eyes, wondering if she could see right through my facade. I felt like I was trapped in a never-ending cycle of disappointment, where every step forward was met with two steps back. My mind was flooded with thoughts of failure, each one more devastating than the last, leaving me gasping for air. It was as if the weight of her words had become a physical burden, crushing me beneath its oppressive force. Every fiber of my being screamed at me to run away, but I was paralyzed by fear, unable to escape the suffocating grip of my own doubts."

Triggering Event: She stood alone in the locker room, her reflection staring back at her from the cold metal. The clock ticked loudly, echoing her racing thoughts. She'd been late again, rushing out before he woke up, leaving him to find a half-eaten breakfast and a note. She regretted not kissing him goodbye, not seeing his smile as he opened his eyes. Today was their anniversary, and she'd forgotten.
Generated Assessment: For fuck's sake, I'm so tired of this shit! I don't even know why I bother trying anymore. It's all his fucking fault anyway. He's just too fucking lazy, that's all. Always waking me up late, making me rush around like a fucking idiot. And what really takes the cake is that he has the nerve to act like it's my problem when I'm already running behind schedule. Like, come on, dude. Can't you see how stressed I am? Do you think I enjoy being late every single day? Newsflash, asshole: I don't. But you know what does make my day worse? You fucking up and forgetting our anniversaries. Yeah, because forgetting isn't hard enough, I have to deal with the fact that you're not even bothered to remember. That's not laziness; that's some serious commitment-phobia right there. You're probably just too busy playing video games or whatever it is you pathetic losers spend your time doing instead of actually living life. So yeah, let's blame him for everything. He's just so fucking selfish, always putting himself first. Who needs an anniversary when you can play Call of Duty instead? I swear, if one more day goes by without him remembering our special day, I'm going to lose it completely. This guy doesn't deserve someone as amazing as me. If anything, he's lucky I still put up with him. At least I get to say "oh well

Triggering Event: She found a receipt in his coat pocket, dinner for two at their favorite restaurant, but no trace of her in the handwritten notes.
Generated Assessment: You are so clueless that you have no idea what's going to happen, don't you? She didn't just leave because she was tired of eating out; there must be some other reason why she vanished. What if she ran into someone from her past? Or maybe she got sick and couldn't go back to work? You're just assuming the worst-case scenario. What if she left because she was embarrassed about how much money we spent? Or perhaps she had an accident while driving home? Don't assume anything until you have all the facts. Maybe she just needed time alone, or maybe she got cold feet. There has to be another explanation. Stop jumping to conclusions! Stop making assumptions! I'm starting to think you might be overreacting. What if... What if... What if... This is ridiculous. We've been together for years, and now you're acting like this isn't normal behavior? I can't believe I'm even thinking these thoughts. It feels like you're pushing me away on purpose. What if... What if... Look, let's take it one step at a time. Let's focus on finding out what happened instead of speculating. You need to calm down and stop worrying about every possible outcome. What if... What if... Seriously, get a grip. This isn't the first time she's gone missing, and it won't be the last. Let's try to stay level-headed here. What if... What if... I know this

Triggering Event: While cleaning out her studio, she found a half-finished painting - his favorite color.
Generated Assessment: "Are you kidding me? How could he leave it like that?! It's my favorite color too! He always said he liked blue more than green, but I'm not stupid. That doesn't mean he wouldn't like this painting. If anything, he'd love it more because it's his favorite color. But why would he just leave it there? Did he think I was going to throw it away? Or worse, did he intentionally put it there for me to find? No way, I know he loves me. This is some kind of sick joke. We're supposed to be getting married soon, and he's doing this? Are we even still together?"

Triggering Event: The retired chef, her hands still calloused from years of kneading dough, noticed a new neighbor had moved in next door. She watched them unload boxes, laughing and helping each other with ease - something she hadn't shared with her ex-husband in decades. As they hung up an old painting, she recognized it immediately: the landscape she'd painted for him as a wedding gift, now tarnished with age but still vibrant with their past. She felt a pang of vengefulness stir within her, a familiar heat that had once fueled her Michelin-starred kitchen.
Generated Assessment: You know how when you see someone doing what you did so well, or they're living a life you never had? It's like being hit by a ton of bricks, right? I mean, my ex was a great cook too, but he was just a hobbyist. He didn't have the same passion, the same fire in his belly that I do. I've spent 40 years perfecting my craft, and every time I look at this woman, I feel like I'm looking into a mirror. Or maybe even worse—like I'm seeing a shadow of what could've been. And don't even get me started on how they're making friends over there, people who would have never come near me if I wasn't the best thing since sliced bread. You know, the ones who actually *care* about cooking? Who appreciate the love and effort that goes into making a dish? They probably think I'm some kind of monster for leaving him, but they wouldn't understand. They wouldn’t know what it’s like to be trapped in a relationship where your partner doesn’t respect your dedication, your hard work, your art. It’s like watching yourself fade away through a lens of resentment. It’s like... I can’t help but feel jealous. That new family of theirs? Just waiting for their son to graduate college, planning trips together, sharing meals that are probably way better than anything I ever made. They’re building a legacy; they’re starting fresh.

Triggering Event: He watches his neighbor, barely older than his own grandchildren, effortlessly carry groceries up to their apartment while he struggles with the same task. "Kids these days," he mutters, "no respect for hard work."
Generated Assessment: He thinks it's funny to watch me struggle with this simple task. It's hilarious how easily his kids can do it now, like they're born with the ability. He must think we're just so much smarter back then because we could do things that seem impossible now. That's why he makes fun of us when he sees our old-school skills. He probably loves seeing how far behind we are, and it gives him a sense of pride. I bet he thinks I'm being lazy by not doing it myself, especially since he looks at me as someone who doesn't have a lot of experience with this sort of thing. Maybe he feels superior because he knows more about it than I do. That's why he teases me about my lack of knowledge, trying to make me feel inferior. It makes him happy to see me struggling, and it gives him an opportunity to brag about how well he does things himself. I don't want to admit that I need help, but deep down, I know he enjoys making me look bad. It's weird how he talks about how hard grocery shopping was back in his day. I guess he's proud of how easy it is for his kids to handle it now. They must be natural-born shoppers because they pick up everything so quickly. He likely thinks he's teaching them valuable life lessons by showing off his skills, and it's all part of his plan to make them better than us. He might even feel superior because he knows more about this

Triggering Event: While grading papers late one evening, she pauses at a student's note: "I wish I had a teacher like you next year." A pang of regret hits her; she remembers how she'd snapped at him last week for being late, hadn't given him the extra help he needed. She imagines him transferring schools, their brief time together lost to her harsh words.
Generated Assessment: Aha! So now I'm feeling pretty guilty about this guy... He was really struggling last week, so I gave him an extension and some extra tutoring. But then, he didn't show up to class that day, and I just felt so frustrated. I couldn't understand why he wouldn't follow through with his commitment. It was like he was trying to sabotage me. But wait... I remember now, it wasn't even his fault that he missed class. His mom was going through a tough time, and they were all staying home because of COVID. That explains everything—she must have been dealing with a lot of stress. And honestly, I can relate. My own life has been chaotic lately too, but I still managed to get my work done. Maybe I was too hard on him? I mean, maybe there are plenty of reasons why he didn't turn in his assignment. Maybe he's dealing with something else entirely that isn't related to me. Or maybe he's just a bad student who doesn't care about doing well. But deep down, I know I could've been more understanding. Maybe if I'd taken things easier on him, he would've opened up and shared what was going on. Who knows? Maybe we could've helped each other out. So yeah... I guess I should take a step back and think before reacting. Yeah, that makes sense. I'm just glad I got to give him the opportunity to catch up eventually. Now let’s see
